blog.name: anaisnein
blog.title: it's all fun and games till someone loses an i
blog.description:
✨Dec 2018 PSA: I am on dreamwidth and discord at the same username, add hashtag three zero four four for discord ✨

devotional spluttering via culturemancy, fully automated luxury tentacle socialism, remote places, aesthetic, ranting. for all aesthetic all the time, slower than here, hit up anodyne-elixir. for gym shit, anaisnein-bigger; any gym stuff here is tagged #project swole for easy avoidance. i also run poetryshrine. if you're here to tell me about papirifagos or correct my bat species taxonomy, don't. obviously, this is a personal blog, and nothing i say here is necessarily reflective of the views of any employer, client or other associate from my responsible adult life.

summary: Keep wondering what the fuck defensive attitude towards aging to develop in advance.
question: Keep wondering what the fuck defensive attitude towards aging to develop in advance.
answer:
good question tbh. I do think part of the problem is that I didn’t have a roadmap or worry one way or another much about it and now it’s hitting me that much harder because it feels so out of a clear blue sky, which is prima facie pretty ridiculous because it ought to be the most predictable thing in the world. but I also wouldn’t want young people to devote a ton of bandwidth to it because why waste your glorious youth fretting.

I seldom bring up cultural representation, because it’s the sort of social justice trope that doesn’t not matter but that too often trends toward the kind of culture war bullshit that ultimately serves ill ends (distraction from material issues, discouragement of coalition building), but this is a case where my gut says raw unchecked -ism is still enough of the problem that representation makes a really major difference. It actually does help me when I see Cate Blanchett or similar being cast in Hot™, sexually charismatic roles like MCU!Hela instead of as presumptively neutered mombot accessories or, worse, grandma generation figures (Spock’s mother for Winona, are you fucking serious).

I am mid Killing Eve rn and it’s speaking to me for a million reasons but a huge one is Sandra Oh’s Eve being allowed to actually be this age, for real, not a super fantasy glam version like Hela, not a super fantasy glam version real world edition like Miranda Priestley (who is role model age to me), but a rendition so grounded in the reality that it actually slightly wigged me out to discover that Phoebe Whoever who’s behind the show is only in her early thirties, how does she know what it’s like – and she still gets to be a. the protagonist (or at least the leading co-protagonist)! b. childless, so the plot and key tropes and characterizations get to be about her herself and not about her mommitude! c. incredibly beguiling, despite not always bothering to defrump and not having the taut sheen of youth any more! and this is partly because of her personality and sense of humor and relatability, which is great, but also it is because she is actually legit hot in a genuine way, and the show acknowledges that robustly and never plays it for mean-spirited laughs like “look how psychotic anyone interested in this crone must obviously be” which would have been horribly easy to fall into. (Like, there are issues there but they’re just issues like people have.) We need more of THIS in the culture. This is actual midlife visibility.

I have a lot more not fully formed points to make, representation isn’t the only or even maybe among the top three most important ones, it just came to mind first, but I don’t have the few hours I need right now to continue in an exploratory blathering vein. Ask again if you want. It’ll cue me to write more. Like, one thing I want to talk about is what’s good about this age, because there is a bunch of good shit. Also I’d like to reemphasize the material in a couple of ways, there’s some practical advice that should be presented routinely and for some reason isn’t.

summary: 2018 Gotham Independent Film Awards: Complete Winners List
title: 2018 Gotham Independent Film Awards: Complete Winners List
body:
2018 Gotham Independent Film Awards: Complete Winners List

The 2018 Gotham Independent Film Awards took place at Cipriani Wall Street in New York City Monday evening. The Oscar race is still taking form but there were definitely a couple of surprises.

The Favourite was expected to take Best Feature given its rising profile and buzz. In addition, the organization had already announced it was bestowing a special Gotham Jury Awardto Olivia Colman, Emma…

View On WordPress

summary: Did I decide to start Killing Eve 10 minutes before bed? Yes. Did I decide to watch because I am in love with Kirby? Yes. Am I...
body: Did I decide to start Killing Eve 10 minutes before bed? Yes. Did I decide to watch because I am in love with Kirby? Yes. Am I already in love with her again 5 minutes into the show? Youuuu betcha

I like TV, Movies, Anime/Manga, Gifs, Actors, Music, Superheroes and Video Games ♥♥♥

summary: I watched the season 1 finale of Killing Eve when it aired and it was really great! I loved it <3 Konstantin actually went to...
caption:
I watched the season 1 finale of Killing Eve when it aired and it was really great! I loved it <3

Konstantin actually went to Eve and Carolyn for help after telling them that Villanelle was after him. It ended up not doing him too much good, as he still got shot and killed by her and in a public place too. I was sad about that, even if she was contracted to kill him, I thought maybe he was too important to her for her to want to kill him and I was actually bitterly disappointed by the betrayal. Although, I guess maybe it was because of how had acted towards her in the end and taking her off assignments that made her not be so bothered by it. I know she’s a psychopath but she did seem to quite like his company, even going as far earlier in the series to give him a birthday party and dress up like him for it. I also really liked Konstantin as a character, he was very interesting to watch and Kim Bodnia played him perfectly. He was funny and caring and a good handler for Villanelle and had all the other stuff going on with the 12, along with these complex relationships with everyone.

Villanelle was on the run for most of the episode and appeared to kill Konstantin then Eve went to to finally see where Villanelle lived only to have her turn up whilst she was there. 

This was after she was fired from her job at MI6 but the girl she asked to track down Villanelle had already found her Parisian apartment and called to tell her about so of course she had to go, but she probably didn’t bargain on bumping in to her.

I really quite liked their scenes where they were bonding and telling each other how they were obsessed with the other as they intrigued each other so much. They are both interesting people and you can tell they’ve never met anyone else who compares to the other, that’s why they intrigue each other so much. 

I loved seeing them lie on the bed together and just be sort of free for a moment of all of life’s burdens and anguish. Just free to be themselves, unrestrained and show their true selves to each other, naked.

For a moment I thought they would end up making out and in bed together because they did seem like they also may be slightly attracted to each other as well, at least emotionally if nothing else, but that’s not what happened at all. It did actually surprise me. 

But instead Eve stabbed Villanelle while they were lying on the bed together, after they’d gotten closer after she’d played with Eve’s hair a little. 

I think Villanelle was truly shocked by her actions and thought they could be friends, it seemed like is was heading that way but it seemed Eve was setting her up, getting her close to do the dirty and stab her. I was shocked too, honestly. I thought maybe they’d run away together and have some weird fairytale ending, in a weird way. It seemed almost like it could have happened from the moments that preceded it. In a weird way, I would’ve liked to see that happen. It would have been oddly sweet. 

Villanelle ran over to the other side of the room in the kitchen and tried shooting at Eve but didn’t hit her, I don’t think she ever actually wanted to hurt her really. She just wanted to escape and that’s just what she did, escape when Eve was too busy trying to dodge bullets, out the door and gone. I think Villanelle did actually see them as friends or that they could be, she saw the potential at least certainly. In a world where she wasn’t really free to have many friends, if any  with her job and everything. I think that’s why she lay down on the bed with her, because she thought she was safe to do so, safe with her to be who she was and be accepted, finally by someone not in her line of work. I think she definitely felt betrayed by Eve stabbing her, you could see it on her face, she wasn’t expecting it I don’t think. Maybe she expected she might attack her but not in that exact moment. Like that moment was pure and unadulterated. 

I think the entire first season was amazing and especially this episode and I can’t wait to see what happens next season, especially as I haven’t read the books which I am glad about because that makes it all new to me. So I don’t know what might happen but I am excited to see what will happen between the two of them and if Eve will get her job back in MI6 or if she will just pursue her by herself with no help. I’m excited to see how and if she tracks her down and when they meet again.

Sandra Oh and Jodie Comer were excellent as Eve and Villanelle and the rest of the cast were great too and I can’t wait to see more of them and their characters.

I heard it shouldn’t be too long before the second season too so I am doubly excited! This is one of the best shows I’ve ever seen and I love it <3

This was after she was fired from her job at MI6 but the girl she asked to track down Villanelle had already found her Parisian apartment and called to tell her about so of course she had to go, but she probably didn’t bargain on bumping in to her.

I really quite liked their scenes where they were bonding and telling each other how they were obsessed with the other as they intrigued each other so much. They are both interesting people and you can tell they’ve never met anyone else who compares to the other, that’s why they intrigue each other so much. 

I loved seeing them lie on the bed together and just be sort of free for a moment of all of life’s burdens and anguish. Just free to be themselves, unrestrained and show their true selves to each other, naked.

For a moment I thought they would end up making out and in bed together because they did seem like they also may be slightly attracted to each other as well, at least emotionally if nothing else, but that’s not what happened at all. It did actually surprise me. 

But instead Eve stabbed Villanelle while they were lying on the bed together, after they’d gotten closer after she’d played with Eve’s hair a little. 

I think Villanelle was truly shocked by her actions and thought they could be friends, it seemed like is was heading that way but it seemed Eve was setting her up, getting her close to do the dirty and stab her. I was shocked too, honestly. I thought maybe they’d run away together and have some weird fairytale ending, in a weird way. It seemed almost like it could have happened from the moments that preceded it. In a weird way, I would’ve liked to see that happen. It would have been oddly sweet. 

Villanelle ran over to the other side of the room in the kitchen and tried shooting at Eve but didn’t hit her, I don’t think she ever actually wanted to hurt her really. She just wanted to escape and that’s just what she did, escape when Eve was too busy trying to dodge bullets, out the door and gone. I think Villanelle did actually see them as friends or that they could be, she saw the potential at least certainly. In a world where she wasn’t really free to have many friends, if any  with her job and everything. I think that’s why she lay down on the bed with her, because she thought she was safe to do so, safe with her to be who she was and be accepted, finally by someone not in her line of work. I think she definitely felt betrayed by Eve stabbing her, you could see it on her face, she wasn’t expecting it I don’t think. Maybe she expected she might attack her but not in that exact moment. Like that moment was pure and unadulterated. 

I think the entire first season was amazing and especially this episode and I can’t wait to see what happens next season, especially as I haven’t read the books which I am glad about because that makes it all new to me. So I don’t know what might happen but I am excited to see what will happen between the two of them and if Eve will get her job back in MI6 or if she will just pursue her by herself with no help. I’m excited to see how and if she tracks her down and when they meet again.

Sandra Oh and Jodie Comer were excellent as Eve and Villanelle and the rest of the cast were great too and I can’t wait to see more of them and their characters.

I heard it shouldn’t be too long before the second season too so I am doubly excited! This is one of the best shows I’ve ever seen and I love it <3

blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

title: Killing Eve, 1x01/02
body:
As others have noted, a theme that emerged early on in “Killing Eve” is the idea that women who kill are inherently non-nurturing and unnatural - how many ‘normal’ women would go out of their way to ruin a child’s day? While Villanelle (BTW, can we talk about how her name is literally “villan” + “elle” - like “villain” + “elle” - “she-villain”…) is clearly disturbed, Eve’s non-conformity is more subtle. “Eve” is the Biblical mother of all humanity and the cause of its descent into sin because she gave into temptation. But, the Eve in the show is portrayed as relatively non-maternal. She technically endangers a minor (Dom), laughs about Frank’s children growing up motherless and with a drunk father, and immediately after that scene, her husband points out that she’s “glowing”. Women are usually described as glowing when they’re pregnant; instead, Eve is glowing because she has a new job hunting down a prolific assassin. If Villanelle is the serpent tempting Eve going forward, I’m interested to see how that temptation plays out. There’s clearly a sexual element, as Villanelle appears to be bisexual and Eve is a little too interested in female assassins - when her husband asks if she’s agreed to work for MI6 just to help stop a killer, she can’t answer.

-Amber

summary: Oooookay, but has anyone listened to this song for Killing Eve that I don’t think I heard anywhere in the series but is...
body:
Oooookay, but has anyone listened to this song for Killing Eve that I don’t think I heard anywhere in the series but is incredibly gay????

Like,

“I rose to kiss her but the flower fell apart?”

“‘Where does love go,’ she said. I said, ‘wherever you are’”

Please give it a listen. Very interesting how it portrays Eve and Villanelle’s relationship.


Edit: it was played in the scene where Konstantin is at his home (thank you @agentlewomancarter !!) I’m still curious as to interpreting this song and it’s lyrics! Let’s discuss!

blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

title: Killing Eve
body:
Knowing that I had to watch the first few episodes of Killing Eve over Thanksgiving break, I made it into a family activity and invited them to watch with me. We all sat down to watch (my sister, her boyfriend, my friend from high school, my dad, mom, and grandma) and were hooked after the first episode. At one point my grandma leaned over to me to ask what class I was supposed to be watching this for, and I responded Literary Lesbians. She then proceeded to ask confused questions about how this was a “lesbian show” because she didn’t really see a prominent lesbian storyline. With only the first episode under our belt, I agreed. Had I not known that we were watching this as part of the ‘psycho lesbian’ I don’t think that I would have read into it and analyzed the female relationship with a queer lense. Since I was watching it with my family, we watched up until episode 7, so I got to see how the female relationship exemplified the ‘psycho lesbian’ trope. Based only on the first episode, or even the first two episodes, it wasn’t obvious that there was going to be a lesbian relationship or even the psychotic lesbian obsession that actually occurs. I’m curious to see how the season ends, and how the next season portrays the relationship between the two main characters.

-Emma

blog.name: keiraquotes
blog.title: Keira Knightley Quotes
blog.description: Quotes from the often foul-mouthed English actress, Keira Knightley. And sometimes quotes from her co-stars, directors, and admirers.

summary: “Sandra Oh is absolutely amazing, but that psycho killer [Jodie Comer’s Villanelle] is the only part that I’ve ever been really,...
body:
“Sandra Oh is absolutely amazing, but that psycho killer [Jodie Comer’s Villanelle] is the only part that I’ve ever been really, really jealous that I didn’t play…. It is such a f—ing amazing psycho, I would really have liked to put my teeth into that. Jodie was f—ing amazing…. I totally loved watching that moment when she turns around in the club and she kills [spoiler] and she’s like a shark coming through that club. I just loved that so much. That image is totally stuck in my head now.”

Keira Knightley on binge watching “Killing Eve”

― Terry Pratchett, The Science of Discworld II: The Globe
